Parkers's Toolbox

Sampling the sun’s atmosphere requires NASA to pack the Parker Solar Probe with a variety of sensing and optical equipment. The gear is aimed at providing answers in four different areas of scientific inquiry.

FIELDS Experiment

Measuring the strength of the magnetic and electric fields in the corona with voltage sensors and magnetometers. It will also gauge the absolute plasma density and electron temperatures.

Solar Wind Electrons

and Protons (SWEAP) Investigation

A trio of sensors will break down the makeup of the solar wind – counting the electrons, protons and helium ions it includes and measuring their velocity, density and temperatures.

Integrated Science

Investigation of the

Sun (IS0IS)

Cataloging the energetic electrons, protons and heavy ions that are accelerated in the atmosphere as well as the inner heliosphere. Handled by the Energetic Particle Instrument – it’s made up of one double-ended high-energy telescope and a pair of low-energy telescopes.

Wide-field Imager for

Solar Probe (WISPR)

Will be capturing images of the solar wind and plasma in the atmosphere. Will derive the 3D structure of the large-scale corona.
